title: Frontotemporal dementia
summary: Frontotemporal dementia (FTD), or frontotemporal degeneration disease,[1] or frontotemporal neurocognitive disorder,[2] encompasses several types of dementia involving the frontal and temporal lobes.[3] FTDs are broadly presented as behavioral or language disorders.[4] The three main subtypes or variant syndromes are a behavioral variant (bvFTD) previously known as Pick's disease,[5][6] and two variants of primary progressive aphasia â€“ semantic variant (svPPA), and nonfluent variant (nfvPPA).[4][6] Two rare distinct subtypes of FTD are neuronal intermediate filament inclusion disease (NIFID), and basophilic inclusion body disease.  Other related disorders include corticobasal syndrome and FTD  with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) FTD-ALS also called FTD-MND.[7]
